descriptions.content:
The article is not generally used in Tibetan. For example, according to the context or the situation, སྨྱུ་གུ་ཡོད་པས། may mean “Have you got a / the / any pen(s)?”

However, this statement ought to be slightly modified: First, the use of the plural marker ཚོ་ (see below xxlink 2.3.2) implies that the (human) noun so qualified is definite, and so it should be preceded in the English translation by the use of the (plural) definite article “the.” Secondly, Tibetan does indeed have a singular indefinite article ཅིག་ that is placed after the noun, but that is used only when the noun is specific:

  • དགེ་རྒན་ཅིག་ “A (certain) teacher”
  • སློབ་གྲྭ་བ་ཅིག་ “A (certain) student”

The singular indefinite article is not used when the noun is generic:

  • ཁོང་དགེ་རྒན་རེད། “He is a teacher.”

But note its use in the following sentence:

  • ཁོང་དགེ་རྒན་ཅིག་རེད། “He’s one (of the) teacher(s).”

The form of the indefinite article ཅིག་ (“a”) should not be confused with that of the cardinal number གཅིག་ (“one”), although the pronunciation of the two is the same.

In Literary Tibetan, the indefinite article has three variants—ཅིག་, ཞིག་, ཤིག་—depending on the final letter of the preceding word.

  • ཅིག་ is used after ག་, ད་, བ་, and the ད་དྲག་
  • ཞིག་ is used after vowels and འ་, ང་, ན་, མ་, ར་, ལ་
  • ཤིག་ is used after ས་

In the spoken language, only the form ཅིག་ is used.

Finally, note that the demonstrative དེ་ is often used in much the same way as a (specific) definite article in the European languages.

  • དེབ་གསར་པ་དེ་ག་པར་འདུག “Where is that / the new book?”
  • བློ་བཟང་གི་སྤུན་སྐྱ་དེ་ཁོང་རེད། “He’s the brother of Lopzang.”
